items.title: Benedict Will Live in Vatican City, but Many Details Remain Undecided
items.abstract: The unusual circumstance of Pope Benedict XVI’s plan to retire at the end of this month presents a series of questions for the Vatican to address.

items.title: To Fight Gridlock, Los Angeles Synchronizes Every Red Light
items.abstract: With the number of cars on the road continuing to rise, boosters of the city’s new synchronized traffic system admit it may not be enough to prevent gridlock from worsening.

items.title: A City of Violent Deaths Tries to Change Its Image
items.abstract: Memorials to victims of drug violence are ubiquitous in Culiacán, Mexico, but officials are slowly asking families’ permission to replace them with discreet marble plaques.

items.title: Ghana’s Crackdown on Chinese Gold Miners Hits One Rural Area Hard
items.abstract: Ghana has soured on the Chinese who have worked in its gold mines for years, exposing China’s risky system of financing for miners and leaving relatives fearing financial ruin.

items.title: Disruptions: How Driverless Cars Could Reshape Cities
items.abstract: While driverless cars might still seem like science fiction, people are considering what they could mean for the city of the future. The short answer is “a lot.”

items.title: In Mexico City, a Battle Over a Building and the Art in Its Shadow
items.abstract: A university building looms over Mexican landscape art, angering artists who call for its demolition. Officials say that’s impossible.

items.title: China to Pillory, or Praise, Cities Based on Water Pollution
items.abstract: The Ministry of Environmental Protection has said it plans to monitor supplies in 338 cities and each month name the 10 best and 10 worst.

items.title: Valuing Culture As Much As Money in an Ancient Chinese City
items.abstract: Members of China’s Uighur ethnic group are working with Chinese efforts to placate them through economic development, opting to also preserve their culture and religion.

items.title: No Driver? Bring It On. How Pittsburgh Became Uber’s Testing Ground
items.abstract: Uber’s experiment with autonomous vehicles is proceeding with the blessing of city officials, who have pretty much just stayed out of the way.

items.title: Chinese City Urges Comrades to Do Their Part and Reproduce
items.abstract: The appeal by Yichang officials, coming so soon after the end of the national one-child policy, was met with howls of amazement and resentment on social media.

items.title: Give Up Owning a Car? An Urban Fantasy
items.abstract: Kara Swisher predicted a shift away from private vehicles. Two readers are dubious.

items.title: On Hong Kong Handover Anniversary, Many Fear Loss of Freedoms
items.abstract: ‘One country, two systems’ was Beijing’s pledge when it took back a former British colony. But concerns over civil liberties are mounting.
keywords: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

items.title: I’m an Engineer, and I’m Not Buying Into ‘Smart’ Cities
items.abstract: Sensor-equipped garbage cans sound cool, but someone still has to take out the trash.

items.title: Driverless Cars Arrive in New York City
items.abstract: Six autonomous cars will shuttle passengers around the Brooklyn Navy Yard for free.

items.title: Inside Kashmir, Cut Off From the World: ‘A Living Hell’ of Anger and Fear
items.abstract: A firsthand look inside Kashmir, the contested region the Indian government has all but cut off from the outside world, found a population that is feeling besieged and furious.

items.title: Italian City Tied to Russia by a Revered Saint Feels the Sting of War in Ukraine
items.abstract: The port of Bari holds relics venerated by Orthodox Christians throughout the former Soviet bloc. Today it is also home to a spillover of tensions from Russia’s invasion.

items.title: An explosion in the Russian-occupied city of Melitopol appears to target a pro-Kremlin leader.
items.abstract: Pro-Kremlin authorities in the city blamed Ukrainian partisans for the blast, which they said had injured two people.

items.title: ‘We Need More Protection:’ Violence in Rural Mexico Ensnares Doctors
items.abstract: As criminal organizations control more territory in less-populated regions, health care workers, caught in the crossfire, grow reluctant to work in such places.

items.title: High Design: The Revolution Taking Over Cannabis Dispensaries
items.abstract: As cannabis legalization has become more widespread, retailers are getting increasingly serious about the design and branding of their shops.
